close_symbols: any global variables referenced or modified by the above functions (identifiers)
explanation:
process_short_param contains no for loops itself, so to determine compliance with the MISRA ‘for loop well‑formed’ rule we must inspect any for loops present in its callees and their callees and any objects those loops use or modify. For each listed symbol:
- process_param__all_cpus, process_param__threads, process_param__thread_per_conn, process_param__epoll, process_param__poll, process_param__select, process_param__empty, process_param__tiny, process_param__medium, process_param__large, process_param__shared, process_param__single, process_param__unique, process_param__connections, process_param__timeout, process_param__version: provide the full definitions/bodies so we can find any for loops they contain and check the three clauses, the loop counter usage, any loop control flags, and whether the loop body (including called functions) modifies loop counters or other objects used in the second/third clauses.
- get_param_value: it is called by several of the above; we need its body to know whether it has side effects that count as modifications in the behaviour of a for loop body (MISRA counts called functions’ behaviour).
- process_long_param: shares callees and may contain similar loop constructs; include to ensure consistent analysis of shared helpers.
- fprintf and stderr: standard I/O calls may appear inside loop bodies; include to confirm their side effects are not modifying loop counters or other objects relevant to loop clauses.
- PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR and enum PerfRepl_param_result: include the definitions so the analyzer has the full type/return-value context (not directly about for loops but required for complete semantic analysis of the function and its returns).
- any global variables referenced or modified by the above functions: loop well‑formedness forbids the second/third clause to use objects that are modified in the loop body (including global state). We must know all globals the callee chain reads/writes (configuration flags, counters, status flags) to verify the rule about permitted objects in the for clauses.

Provide the source (bodies) of the listed functions and the declarations/definitions of any globals they touch; with these symbols the next agent can locate every for loop reachable from process_short_param and check the MISRA conditions (loop counter identity, permitted objects in clauses, and absence of modifications to loop counter from the body or called functions).
